9231/13

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 730, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 235, 88]]<|/det|>
It is given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 101, 712, 120]]<|/det|>
\[\alpha +\beta +\gamma = 3,\quad \alpha^{2} + \beta^{2} + \gamma^{2} = 5,\quad \alpha^{3} + \beta^{3} + \gamma^{3} = 6.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 133, 586, 152]]<|/det|>
The cubic equation \(x^{3} + bx^{2} + cx + d = 0\) has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 165, 346, 182]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(b, c\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 146, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 73, 861, 108]]<|/det|>
Express \(\frac{1}{r(r + 1)(r + 2)}\) in partial fractions and hence use the method of differences to find

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 114, 576, 155]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{n}\frac{1}{r(r + 1)(r + 2)}. \]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 125, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 833, 186, 852]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 831, 468, 871]]<|/det|>
Deduce the value of \(\sum_{r = 1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{r(r + 1)(r + 2)}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 839, 920, 858]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 83, 97, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 541, 112]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) is given by \(\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 129, 144, 148]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 128, 724, 149]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) represents a sequence of two geometrical transformations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 160, 853, 181]]<|/det|>
State the type of each transformation, and make clear the order in which they are applied. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 378, 143, 396]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 377, 917, 413]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(\theta\), for \(0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \pi\), for which the transformation represented by \(\mathbf{M}\) has exactly one invariant line through the origin, giving your answers in terms of \(\pi\). [9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 648, 92]]<|/det|>
The plane \(\varPi\) has equation \(\mathbf{r} = - 2\mathbf{i} + 3\mathbf{j} + 3\mathbf{k} + \lambda (\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{k}) + \mu (2\mathbf{i} + 3\mathbf{j})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 104, 144, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 792, 123]]<|/det|>
Find a Cartesian equation of \(\varPi\) , giving your answer in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 897, 524]]<|/det|>
The line \(l\) passes through the point \(P\) with position vector \(2\mathbf{i} - 3\mathbf{j} + 5\mathbf{k}\) and is parallel to the vector \(\mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 536, 146, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 581, 555]]<|/det|>
Find the position vector of the point where \(l\) meets \(\varPi\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 536, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 458, 91]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between \(l\) and \(\varPi\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 186, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 504, 512, 523]]<|/det|>
Find the perpendicular distance from \(P\) to \(\varPi\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 665, 95]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r = 2\cos \theta (1 + \sin \theta)\), for \(0\leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 107, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 107, 729, 126]]<|/det|>
Find the polar coordinates of the point on \(C\) that is furthest from the pole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 235, 88]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 395, 146, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 920, 413]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the region bounded by \(C\) and the initial line, giving your answer in exact form. [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 94, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 425, 104]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{4x + 5}{4 - 4x^2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 125, 144, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 125, 487, 144]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 125, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 375, 186, 393]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 375, 554, 393]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of any stationary points on \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 375, 920, 393]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 678, 88]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\), stating the coordinates of the intersections with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 70, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 450, 144, 468]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 439, 920, 490]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curve with equation \(y = \left|\frac{4x + 5}{4 - 4x^2}\right|\) and find in exact form the set of values of \(x\) for which \(4|4x + 5| > 5|4 - 4x^2|\). 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 471, 920, 490]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]
